Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Distributed Function Computation and Multiterminal Data Compression

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research addresses the theory and design of algorithms for an efficient local computation by multiple network terminals of shared functions of all their observed correlated data. Efficient communication among the terminals facilitates efficient computation. Applications include: computing the average, variance, maximum, minimum and parity of observed data in a colocated network of wireless sensors that make correlated measurements. This objective is connected closely to the design of algorithms for the efficient compression of data for storage and transmission purposes, as well as of algorithms for assuring data security. A main goal of the project is to characterize explicitly these connections, thereby leading to the development of new and efficient algorithms for data compression, function computation and network security.

The technical approach involves a formulation of the underlying problems and their analysis, using an information theoretic framework. This will enable the development of a principle of "entropy decomposition of total shared randomness" in a network model to address difficult problems in multiuser information theory of which rate-efficient function computation is a leading example. In particular, an application of source coding algorithms in distributed function computation will be studied. Specific groups of open problems chosen for investigation address a general class of multiterminal models for function computation and data compression. This choice is motivated by, and is of compelling interest to, the theory and engineering practice of network function computation and source coding, as well as network security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project took a network information theoretic approach to explore innate connections that exist between distributed function computation in a network, multiuser source coding and network security.

The overarching goal was to understand and establish explicit and precise descriptions of these important connections, leading to the development of information theoretic principles for secure distributed network computation and secret key agreement. Specific objectives include a characterization of fundamental performance limits and the structure of associated protocols.A second major goal was to disseminate the findings of this project among a broad community of researchers in computer science and cryptography, in addition to the traditional fields of information and communication theory.

Both goals were accomplished. First, precise conditions were determined under which network nodes can compute a given function of their collective data using public communication in such a way as to not reveal the function value to an observer of said communication. These conditions brought out connections to the problems of secret key generation and multiterminal data compression (without security restrictions). In addition to establishing fundamental performance limits, structural properties of underlying protocols were also revealed. Second, a monograph entitled ``Multiterminal Secrecy by Public Communication,'' authored by P. Narayan and H. Tyagi, Foundations and Trends in Communications and Information Theory, Ed. S. Verdú, Now Publishers, October 2016, is expected serve the mentioned objective of broad dissemination.
